text: The functions of these tribunals include determining both the factual and the legal issues arising in cases concerning administrative offences (Verwaltungsübertretungen).
label: non-argumentative

text: The instrument of ratification of the Convention deposited by the Austrian Government on 3 September 1958 contains, inter alia, a reservation worded as follows:
label: non-argumentative

text: The provisions of Article 5 (art. 5) of the Convention shall be so applied that there shall be no interference with the measures for the deprivation of liberty prescribed in the laws on administrative procedure, BGBl [Federal Official Gazette] No. 172/1950, subject to review by the Administrative Court or the Constitutional Court as provided for in the Austrian Federal Constitution.
label: non-argumentative

text: Mr Pramstaller applied to the Commission on 18 May 1990. He relied on Article 6 paras. 1, 2 and 3 (art. 6-1, art. 6-2, art. 6-3) of the Convention, complaining (a) that he had been unable to bring his case before a tribunal for the determination of a criminal charge against him and (b) that he had not had a fair trial in that the burden of proof had been on him, the accused.
label: non-argumentative

text: On 10 May 1993 the Commission declared the application (no. 16713/90) admissible in so far as it concerned the complaint that the applicant had not been able to bring his case before a tribunal within the meaning of Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1) of the Convention.
label: non-argumentative

text: In its report of 19 May 1994 (Article 31) (art. 31), it expressed the unanimous opinion that there had been a violation of that provision (art. 6 1).
label: non-argumentative

text: It further expressed the opinion that the lack of hearing in the Administrative Court raised no separate issue.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant complained of a violation of Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1) of the Convention, which provides:
label: non-argumentative

text: In the determination of ... any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing ... by an independent and impartial tribunal ...
label: non-argumentative

text: He had, he maintained, been denied the right to a "tribunal" and to a hearing before such a body.
label: non-argumentative

text: Whether there was a "criminal charge"
label: non-argumentative

text: In Mr Pramstaller's submission, the administrative criminal offence of which he was accused gave rise to a "criminal charge". This was not disputed by the Government.
label: non-argumentative

text: In order to determine whether an offence qualifies as "criminal" for the purposes of the Convention, it is first necessary to ascertain whether or not the provision (art. 6-1) defining the offence belongs, in the legal system of the respondent State, to criminal law; next the "very nature of the offence" and the degree of severity of the penalty risked must be considered (see, among other authorities, the Öztürk v. Germany judgment of 21 February 1984, Series A no. 73, p. 18, para. 50, and the Demicoli v. Malta judgment of 27 August 1991, Series A no. 210, pp. 15-17, paras. 31-34).
label: non-argumentative

text: Austria's reservation in respect of Article 5 (art. 5) of the Convention
label: non-argumentative

text: According to the Government, the procedure in question was covered by Austria's reservation in respect of Article 5 (art. 5) of the Convention.
label: non-argumentative

text: There could be no doubt that by the reference in that reservation to "measures for the deprivation of liberty" the Austrian Government had meant to include proceedings resulting in such measures.
label: non-argumentative

text: Any other construction would not only lack coherence; it would also run counter to the authorities' intention, which had been to remove from the scope of the Convention the whole administrative system, including the substantive and procedural provisions of administrative criminal law.
label: non-argumentative

text: That would be so even in a case where, as in this instance, the accused was merely fined, in so far as default on payment of that fine would entail committal to prison.
label: non-argumentative

text: Admittedly, the Tyrol Building Regulations Act 1978 was not one of the four laws designated in the reservation.
label: non-argumentative

text: However, one of those laws, the Administrative Criminal Justice Act, stated in section 10 that, except as otherwise provided, the general administrative laws were to determine the nature and severity of sanctions.
label: non-argumentative

text: It mattered little in this respect that section 53 of the Tyrol Building Regulations Act, which was applied in the present case, had been enacted after the reservation had been deposited, because that provision merely clarified the substance of an existing obligation laid down in the Tyrol Building Regulations Act 1901.
label: non-argumentative

label: non-argumentative

text: Under Article 50 (art. 50) of the Convention,
label: non-argumentative

text: If the Court finds that a decision or a measure taken by a legal authority or any other authority of a High Contracting Party is completely or partially in conflict with the obligations arising from the ... Convention, and if the internal law of the said Party allows only partial reparation to be made for the consequences of this decision or measure, the decision of the Court shall, if necessary, afford just satisfaction to the injured party.
label: non-argumentative

text: The Delegate of the Commission left the matter of just satisfaction to the discretion of the Court.
label: non-argumentative

text: In respect of pecuniary damage, the applicant claimed repayment of the fine imposed on him, that is to say ATS 60,000. He also claimed ATS 20,000 for non-pecuniary damage.
label: non-argumentative

text: The Government contended that the Court had no jurisdiction to quash convictions pronounced by national courts or to order repayment of fines.
label: non-argumentative

text: Moreover, it could not, in awarding reparation, speculate as to what the outcome of the proceedings would have been if the applicant had had access to a tribunal within the meaning of Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1) of the Convention.
label: non-argumentative

text: The Court agrees.
label: non-argumentative

text: In addition, Mr Pramstaller claimed the sum of ATS 203,763 for the costs and expenses incurred in the proceedings first in the domestic courts and then before the Convention institutions.
label: non-argumentative

text: The Government expressed the view that only the proceedings in the Administrative Court - which had given rise to the alleged violations - and those in Strasbourg could be taken into account.
label: non-argumentative

text: They also contested the quantum of the costs, but they were prepared to reimburse a total of ATS 300,000 in respect of the Umlauft, Pramstaller, Palaoro and Pfarrmeier cases, the applicants in all these cases having been represented by the same lawyer.
label: non-argumentative

text: Making an assessment on an equitable basis, having regard to the information in its possession and its case-law, the Court awards Mr Pramstaller ATS 100,000.
label: non-argumentative

text: Holds that Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1) of the Convention applies in this case;
label: non-argumentative

text: Holds that there has been a violation of that Article (art. 6-1) as regards access to a court;
label: non-argumentative

text: Holds that it is not necessary to examine the complaint based on the lack of a hearing in the Administrative Court;
label: non-argumentative

text: Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months, 100,000 (one hundred thousand) Austrian schillings in respect of costs and expenses;
label: non-argumentative

text: Dismisses the remainder of the claim for just satisfaction.
label: non-argumentative

text: I concur in the Court's finding that Article 6 (art. 6) has been violated, but cannot agree with its reasoning.
label: non-argumentative

text: The powers of the Administrative Court must be assessed in the light of the fact that the court in this case was sitting in proceedings that were of a criminal nature for the purposes of the Convention.
label: non-argumentative

text: I will refrain from a structural criticism of this paragraph.
label: non-argumentative

text: I cannot help noting, however, that here again the Court finds it necessary to remark that when it is being assessed whether or not the Administrative Court is to be considered a court that affords the safeguards of Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1), "regard must be had to the complaints raised in that court".
label: non-argumentative

text: One looks in vain, however, for evidence of this methodological principle being put into practice: there does not follow any analysis of what the applicant argued before the Administrative Court, nor is there any trace of "regard" to these arguments in the assessment of the adequacy of the Administrative Court's jurisdiction.
label: non-argumentative

text: For the rest, I refer to the methodological objections to this "test" that I raised in paragraph 18 of my separate opinion in the case of Fischer v. Austria (judgment of 26 April 1995, Series A no. 312).
